children.text: The concrete slab has been cut back, exposing the steel reinforcement bars on the edge of the slab, which are starting to rust. This will continue to do so over time, and can possibly lead to the future cracking of the slab as well as its possible long-term failure. Additionally, the throat width of the slab edge beam may have been reduced to less than the minimum specified by the engineer.
It is a requirement of section 5.3.2 Reinforcement of AS 2870 Residential Slabs and Footings, that
‘Reinforcement in rafts and slabs shall be placed with minimum concrete cover of the reinforcement shall be 40 mm to unprotected ground and 40 mm to external exposure’ .

The builder will need to have the original design engineer investigate the width of the remaining slab throat and either certify it in its current state or design a rectification procedure if considered necessary, then properly cut back and treat the steel reinforcement in these areas prior to back-filling the slab edge. The owner should request a copy of the engineer’s comments and/or recommendations and ensure that any rectification work is carried out under the supervision and approval of the building surveyor.
